utterances: The chalk, as they would say in college basketball parlance.
The overall No. 1 seed is the continuing fallout over sexual harassment, as you can imagine - just a huge story.
It's touched every industry - going to be tough to beat.

But then you look at the other No. 1s, and they're pretty strong too, including James Comey being fired - the former FBI director - the ensuing Russia probe by Robert Mueller that came out of that, and of course, the tree that almost everything in 2017 stems from - President Trump's inauguration, David.
Which was a big, defining moment for this country.
So are there sleepers?
I mean, can we continue this metaphor and talk about schools or stories that might sneak up on us and, you know, be considered a big deal?
Yeah, the only time that a 16 seed has defeated a 1 seed in college basketball history was in 1998 when the Harvard women's team beat Stanford.
So there's never...
Uh-huh, I watched that game, Domenico, you should know.
There has never been a 1-16 upset in the men's tournament.
You know, will the trend continue in this tournament?
I don't know.
Let's see.
Some on Twitter have been threatening to advance Trump looks at eclipse over him being inaugurated, but kind of - that just feels like trolling.
(Laughter) Yeah.
Rouhani easily defeated a hard-line cleric.
What did it feel like?
So, what if he doesn't win?
Does all of this hope and transformation go away?
No, I don't think so.
I think that the fact that he has come this far is in itself historic.
But Taylor says it ain't over til it's over.
And he'll be watching closely.
Don't know.
I'm just going to kind of leave it on the shelf to gather dust.
The army has been brought in.
Do you get the sense at all that things are getting under control?
How safe are you feeling?
Well, in our homes, we are safe really because now, it's isolated at - presently, it's isolated at three points in Colaba area.
But the reports say there were about 25 terrorists, and there could be local support.
And they're on the loose.
That leaves a very unnerving feeling because, if they're on the loose, and they're on a suicide mission, and they're not - you know, they could strike at any point of time.
So, it does definitely leave an unnerving feeling.
As long as you're home, you're secure.
But one doesn't know what to expect tomorrow.
Mr.
Doctor, I understand that you are a Muslim.
Is that correct?
That is correct, yeah.
So far, there has not been official confirmation of who's responsible for these attacks, but they have been attributed, at least in part, to Islamic militants.
How do you think the situation there might affect Hindu-Muslim relations in Mumbai?
Well, the people claiming responsibility announced, they're called the Deccan Mujahideen.
And one doesn't know the veracity of that, whether they are a front or not.
But hopefully, one hopes and prays that this won't deteriorate into a communal incident or a communal clash, that we'll stand together.

And I think Bombay has so far stood together and realized that, look, these are international acts of terror, and one can't hold one particular race or religion responsible because no religion or race preaches such inhuman acts of violence on innocent people.
So, I hope and pray that this stays as an international act of terror from people who are misguided and irresponsible and doesn't escalate into anything more.
I sincerely hope and pray that that will stay that.
Arif Doctor spoke to us from his home in Mumbai, India.
Thank you for speaking with us, and please stay safe.
Thank you.
This is Day to Day.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
Coming up, on the eve of Halloween, we've got one couple's frightful tale from the grips of a ghoulish housing market.
First, though, we continue our series of conversations about race in the presidential race.
Celeste Headlee spoke with three African-American business executives in Detroit.
I sat down around a lunch table at Seldom Blues in Detroit with three very different business people.
Derand Sanders (ph) helps develop tanks for the U.S.
Army.
Frank Taylor owns Seldom Blues as well as a couple other popular restaurants in the city, and Nicole Lamb-Hale is a managing partner for the national law firm, Foley and Lardner (ph).
I asked them what Senator Obama's candidacy means to them on a personal level, aside from party politics.
It means a lot to me on a number of levels.
And I have to tell you, this morning, I voted because I will be absent from my community.
I'll be helping with voter-protection efforts around the state.
But it really struck me this morning, when I actually filled in the bubble next to his name, that this is truly historic.
And I just thought of my grandparents.
I thought of my parents.
I thought of my children.
I mean, it was almost spiritual for me.
Derand Sanders says he hasn't had the strong emotional response to Obama's campaign that others have had.
He was in Denver when the senator accepted his party's nomination.
It was a spectacular moment.
But I remember there were others that were there, and they were crying, and they were so emotional.
And as they were engaging me, they said, don't you see this?
They were shaking me and hitting me - we've got it!
And it was hard for me to really dive deep into and fully understand that appreciation.
Frank Taylor is a little less restrained in his response.
I guess, if I was by myself sitting here, I'd be shouting.
Really, I'm a believer.
(Soundbite of laughter)
And that's how God works.
I mean, why He would make a person that would be of hatred, and say, I'm going to vote for him because I really think that this is the person that could make it happen.

Taylor is talking about those voters who've been quoted in the news as saying they do harbor racial prejudice, but they're willing to vote for Obama because they think he'll be able to fix the economy.
And I asked what they thought about the shouts of terrorist at some rallies and the effigies hung in trees.
What's your response to that?
Or do you have concerns over what this may mean in terms of racial relations?
That's a - yes, it's a tough one.
But, you know, some people would say that it's brought the country closer together.
Some people would say, well, it's divided because, you know, one would say, well, you're only voting because he's African-American and so on and so forth.
But you're going to have certain issues, no matter with who he is.
I mean, McCain is going to have them.
I mean, he's had them with Palin charts and so on and so forth.
But no, I don't think so.
Lamb-Hale says the financial crisis is forcing Americans to look beyond color and focus on more important issues.
It's amazing that, you know, the bounce that McCain got with the Palin nomination.
And then, when we had our troubles with the market, it's almost like people woke up and said, wait a minute, you know, pigs and lipstick don't matter.
And I think it just really made people wake up and say, look, what's important here?
Lamb-Hale says a lot of the older folk in her family were hesitant to support Obama at first.
It's funny.
I think of my mother, who was a bit afraid to believe it could happen, you know.
I think, for her, it was a fear of disappointment.
Many didn't believe that they would see this in their lifetimes.
You know, I have a 91-year-old grandfather, who's in Arkansas, who's just thrilled to death that he'll be able to vote for who he hopes will be the first black president.
So, it's just wonderful.
All three plan to watch the election returns on November 4th with their families, and all of them expect it to be a night they'll be talking about with their children and their grandchildren.
I'd be shocked if that happens.
I'd look instead at the 6-seeded Donald Trump Jr.'s email revelations - pretty big story to advance in the second round in that bracket.
But it's going to be kind of hard for it to get past No. 3, gun violence.
It was pretty sweeping, thematic story of the year, obviously.
I'd also watch deportations and DACA at No. 5.
There's been a lot of chatter about that, and lots of people in early brackets that have been coming in, picking that over Trump being inaugurated.
And the one story a lot of people can't seem to let go - Anthony Scaramucci's 10 days in the White House.
It is, by the way, an ironically seeded 10 seed to upset No. 7, New York truck attack - obviously, far more serious and important, but that's what happens when people decide.
It's amazing.

And I guess - I mean, you know, stories are things that people internalize personally, so something like gun violence - I mean, it's something that someone might take much more seriously and consider it a much bigger story.
So you actually want people to, quote, unquote, ""play"" - right?
- and give you a sense of what they think - or one story is more or less important than the other.
Absolutely.
Go on my Twitter feed - @DomenicoNPR - download the bracket there - it's pinned - submit it by noon today in that tweet thread.
And I have promised a very special NPR prize.
And David, I'm sorry to do this to you.
I know it's the first time you're hearing this, but I promised them your voice on their answering machine.
I hope that's OK with you.
I don't think anyone wants that.
(Laughter).
But if they do, I'm more than happy to do it, so I will play along.
NPR's Domenico Montanaro.
Domenico, thanks.
Hey, you're welcome.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
OK, we're going to turn now to Afghanistan, where a suicide bomber blew himself up near the Afghan intelligence agency yesterday in Kabul.
